headline.main: Men's Health: Another Risk of Obesity: Dying in a Car Crash

docs.lead_paragraph: Men are at higher risk of being killed in car accidents if they are obese, researchers have found.
docs.snippet: Men are at higher risk of being killed in car accidents if they are obese, researchers have found.

docs.lead_paragraph: I am having difficulties finding out what illnesses can affect whether someone should fly or not. My friend has had deep-vein thrombosis, is obese and has high blood pressure. I say we should take the train. Can you help? Susie Young, Toronto The best advice I can give is for your friend to consult her doctor. Deep-vein thrombosis is a serious health hazard and, in spite of what the airlines may say, there is published medical research to indicate a link between the condition and flying. It is clear that lack of movement, cramped seats and reduced air pressure in the cabin have a combined impact on blood-clotting mechanisms. And obesity is an additional risk factor, according to Dr. Richard Dawood, a Londoner who specializes in travel-related medicine. At an altitude of 30,000 feet, the cabin is pressurized to 8,000 feet, the equivalent of sitting on top of a mountain. The low cabin air pressure makes your heart and lungs work harder and can be dangerous for people prone to strokes or who have heart problems.
docs.snippet: I am having difficulties finding out what illnesses can affect whether someone should fly or not. My friend has had deep-vein thrombosis, is obese and has high blood pressure. I say we should take the train. Can you help?

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Veterans Health Program Unveiled

byline.original: By SEWELL CHAN (NYT); Compiled by John Sullivan

docs.abstract: New York City joins in national program to educate veterans about obesity, nutrition and diabetes (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the federal secretary of veterans affairs, R. James Nicholson, announced a program yesterday to educate veterans about obesity, nutrition and the risks of diabetes. The program is part of HealthierUS Veterans, a program of the Departments of Veterans Affairs and Health and Human Services. There are 312,000 veterans in the city. Nationally, two-thirds of veterans receiving health care from Veterans Affairs are overweight or obese and one-fifth have diabetes, compared with 7 percent of the general population. SEWELL CHAN (NYT)
docs.snippet: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the federal secretary of veterans affairs, R. James Nicholson, announced a program yesterday to educate veterans about obesity, nutrition and the risks of diabetes. The program is part of HealthierUS Veterans, a program...

headline.main: A Ray of Hope For Diabetics; This Drug Helps Shed Pounds

docs.lead_paragraph: The users call the drug Lizzie, the Big Brother or sometimes Gilly. On blogs they rave over its uncanny ability to melt away pounds, although some are wary of its side effects, which can include nausea and strange welts. The users are not fad dieters or methamphetamine addicts, but people with diabetes. And the subject of their rhapsodies is not a gray-market diet pill sold on late-night television but Byetta, a federally approved diabetes medicine, available only by prescription, whose popularity and sales have soared since its introduction last June.
docs.snippet: A new drug for diabetics, Byetta, helps users lose weight, a contrast to the dangerous weight gain that can accompany other diabetes medicines.
